newsitem.title: UK: North Sea crude market ends week with healthy glow.
newsitem.headline: North Sea crude market ends week with healthy glow.

text.p: The North Sea crude market ended the week close to where it started after unremarkable but consistent buying kept differentials fairly steady.
"It's still looking like a very healthy market," said one trader. "It's not fantastically strong but every cargo is getting a pretty good price."

All of the three Brent cargoes nominated from the paper chains on Friday were kept early. One, loading Aug 18-20, was sold on by a U.S. refiner to a Wall street trader at Aug Brent +3 cents, three cents down from a deal done on Thursday.
Outright prices mostly reversed early gains by late in the day. September Brent was trading two cents down at $18.92 a barrel at 1752 GMT.
Brent intermonth spreads held firm, with August/September talked at +25/40 cents late in the day after trading at +30 cents earlier. Sept/Oct moved up a notch to -3/-1 cents.
CFDs for next week (Aug 4-8) held a strong backwardation of around 12-15 cents to the following week (Aug 11-15) which traded at September Brent parity in the afternoon.

Other North Sea grades were actively traded but mostly on a confidential basis. A prompt Statfjord was heard to have changed hands at a slightly weaker level than recent trades, but still above Dated Brent +20 cents. A Statfjord, Oseberg and Gullfaks C loading later in August all fetched steady premiums, traders said.
Statfjord cargoes with later loading dates were benefiting from a three-day delay in the August programme, they said.
Improving margins, helped by news that three catalytic crackers in northwest Europe were out of action, were helping to bolster refinery interest.
Sour crude in the Mediterranean was steady but buyers were starting to lose interest with expectations growing that Iraqi exports could be flowing by the middle of this month.
Benchmark Russian Urals crude was still pegged at around Dated Brent -60 cents but was seen set to fall.
